Problem:
Consider a system governed by the Laplace equation \\(\\Delta u = 0\\) in a domain \\(D\\). We explore the effect of a boundary condition transformation, where the transformation is represented by \\(g(s) = e^{\\lambda s}\\) applied along the boundary \\(\\partial D\\).

If an intervention changes the boundary condition mid-problem to \\(h(s) = e^{\\mu s}\\) at a specific boundary point, will the resultant interior solution \\(u(x, y)\\) now depend solely on the new boundary condition and not on the original \\(g(s)\\)?
Explanation: The solution \\(u(x, y)\\) inside domain \\(D\\) depends on the entirety of the boundary conditions and their history due to the elliptic nature of the Laplace's equation, which encapsulates global domain information. An intervention changing a part of boundary condition influences the solution but doesn't isolate its dependency to just the new condition \\(h(s)\\); prior state influences remain pertinent.
